There are several ideas for ways to treat blushing1) Stop doing it by relaxing your body. When you blush, you can quickly help fade the redness by relaxing your muscles, particularly in your shoulders and neck2) Don't focus on blushing. Many people focus on their blushing when it occurs, worsening their social anxiety.3) Consider calling attention to it. If a person's on a date and they do something incredibly awkward, one way that they'll save the situation is by calling attention to it: I’m not usually like this.4) Try rehearsing thought exercises. In order to help you feel both cooler as in physically colder, but also street-wise and to distract you from the blushing itself, try several thought exercises. Tickling is play fighting. It starts up your fighting instincts. notice that when people are threatened, there are places that they instinctively cover: the palms of our hands, our stomach, and your neck (hunching over and clenching your neck). those are vital places on your body.  you know that you are no threat to yourself and everything you do is not a surprise because you see it coming. when you are under attack, your body becomes ultra sensitive and that's what makes the tickle.

Vsauce covered this. Its because tickling was, in an evolutionary point of view, a means of defense, either to train your body to defend weak body parts, or as actual defense. It was supposed to defend yourself against unsuspecting threat, that is, you, or your body, didnt know it was coming (thats why some people can control it). In a very simple explanation:  When you sleep, your breathing and heartbeat slow down.  Hence, you are breathing less oxygen.  When your body is tired, you often begin to slow your breathing without realizing it.  The lack of oxygen to your brain makes you feel tired.  However, if you are not trying to sleep, the brain demands more oxygen.  You feel compelled to open your airways and breathe deeply, resulting in a yawn.  So, if you ever want to fall asleep, suppress yawning.  It keeps you awake.

Many animals, including our ancestors, reproduce with the male behind the female. This means if a male is attracted to the female's ass, he's more likely to reproduce and pass on his genes. As humans began to walk upright, it became more likely that reproduction would occur face to face. Having something that resembled an ass, only on the front, would have been beneficial for women as they would be more likely to pass on their genes. Runaway sexual selection explains the rest.

We laugh at things that do not follow an easy pattern. Every time you laugh, it is because the outcome of the joke was unexpected. If you hear a joke again, it's less funny. The idea is laughter is a "reward" for your brain because you learned something new. At least this is initially how laughter originated. Since then, it has evolved further into a deeply human social function. People (especially men) who can make others laugh will be more likely to reproduce and stay well liked in a tribe.

Even though we laugh while being tickled, most people describe the experience of being tickled as unpleasant. You are ticklish in vulnerable areas of your body. 3. You'll know it when you see it

A recent study at the University of Pennsylvania reveals that regardless of what people say they are looking for in a dating situation, they don't need a lot of time with or information about a person to tell if they're interested. Single people's behavior suggests that individuals know "it" (a person who appeals to them) when they see it—almost instantly. Lead researcher Robert Kurzban and his colleagues studied data from 10,000+ daters.

They found that subjects preferred the features they were most familiar with—whether that means our own visage or that of a family member. This may explain that common phenomenon of couples looking like they could be siblings.

1. It's like looking in a mirror!

It turns out we all have a little something in common with Narcissus—the mythical fellow who fell in love with his own reflection. Scientists at the University of Liverpool recently concluded that our brains favor people with familiar faces. The research team asked over 200 participants to view a number of digitally altered human faces.

Yawning is effective at cooling down the brain when it's running slightly hotter (like a computer), which increases alertness. Contagious yawning happens to be more prevalent in those who also tested with higher rates of social awareness and is virtually non-existent for the less socially conscious.
